Review Text: Soft silicone rabbit with a hard plastic bottom (where power button is located). Charge the night light out of its bum-which my children thought was hilarious. It glows red when charging, and turns green when done so we knew exactly when we could pull the plug. Our other animal night light doesn’t have that feature-we just charge it and unplug it based on the timing of this one. It’s a bit tricky to get the light selection at first. I found the best way to select the lighting option is to squeeze both sides of the bunny (as seen in video) after you power it on. First squeeze is dim light, 2nd squeeze makes it brighter, 3rd squeeze it goes into color changing mode. It’s a slow gradual color change (the video is sped up so all the colors are shown). When you get to a color you want the light to stay on at, you can double squeeze the bunny (this bit is tricky) and it’ll stay that color the whole time. Took me a while to get the right double clicks (you sort of feel an internal click when squeezing the bunny’s belly from both sides). My 5 year old wanted her bunny to be pink. And it does light up the room-see photo. If you’re not looking at it, it does provide a nice glow to the whole room.  Either I was super tired or the glow wasn’t too bright, but I was able to fall asleep with this night light on. I need it pitch black in my room to fall asleep, but while putting my kiddos to sleep the first night we had this I also really fell asleep too! Usually I sneak out after they fall asleep, but nope I fell asleep right alongside with them. We didn’t get one with remote, but I think it would help with being able to select the color you want immediately instead of cycling through the colors to get what you want at least once if not twice caused you missed clicking the bunny correctly at the right color. Would recommend.

Review Text: The good:  Overall its a great looking kit, the price mark is right, and would be a great addition to the collection of Lego kits our family has enjoyed for many years (3 generations). The bad:  This one is a weak design.  the front and back "bumper" assemblies sit on a "twosie" so if my grandson is acting out with it and pushes a disabled car off the road using its bumper, the whole bumper assembly falls off.  A very frustrating thing. Also, the blue hood part doesn't "snap" into place.  It pops off.  and the white upper fender parts on side of the blue hood part are actually only held in place on a "onesie".  There's no strength in this bumper assembly and access to the inside to put the action figure in the "cockpit" requires a disassembly of the top.  The whole design is not sturdy.  Most kits have strength built in with overlapping or specialty pieces.  This one is just not durable enough to withstand normal play.  If you use it as just a display, then you will not mind its lack of assembled strength.  You definitely can not toss it in the "lego box", toy box, or drop on the floor - it will not survive even the lightest of abuse.  There's just too many pieces that will randomly fall off for this kit to be fully enjoyed.  I'm thinking of using glue to hold it all together or use my lego pieces to reinforce it, but something needs to be re-thought.  I can not recall any other kit that this is such a big problem. The instructions had some weak moments as well.  The last time I checked a 5 year old can't multiply but you can explain a 2X, 4X, etc. means twice or double and if he understands that he can assemble most of this with adult supervision.  But for a 5 year old to use these instructions without adults nearby to ask what color, or the red outlines, clear pieces of color, the direction of hinging parts, etc. is asking a little much to let him on his own figure it out.  I have a almost three year old grandchild and of course this is too complicated for a 3 or 4 but we do it together and have fun.  Of course your child is a genius and can put any lego kit together on their own,  but MOST kids of this age group (2-5) are still putting everything in their mouth and should be using duplo blocks.  Most of these "city" lego kits are put together by adults and if your kid is too young to be left alone with all the small parts to swallow is not the responsibility of Lego.  I use similar kits with a duplo city we built and the classic "city" lego kits are more to scale for it.  So I can let him role play with it (3yrs) while I watch but I don't leave him alone with it.  Its just too delicate to play with anyway so for my expected use, this kit is a bust.

Review Text: I enjoy buying Legos kits for my grandkids.  As a former teacher, and a conservative, I love that legos inspires kids to use their brains.  Then they can use their imaginations to play with them.  And after a while tear the kits apart and do it all again.  The Legos brand is well known and trustworthy to be great quality.  I have helped the kids build dozens of kits and not once was a single piece missing or deformed. Even when I couldn't find a part, the kids did.  I have gotten other brands of kits and while the blocks themselves are very good quality, the instructions are not up to Legos quality. Note, the only reason for the lack of a perfect star review is because three of the last 4 items it got were crushed in shipment.  I blame the packaging, not the product itself. Another note I would rather NOT get the kit on a Sunday and instead be assured that it is not crushed.
